captions.text:
This might look like your standard
Volkswagon GTI

and that's because it is. Now this is a
Volkswagen Golf R.

Past the badges the differences are hard
to spot.

Volkswagen seems to enjoy subtlety but
you might be surprised to hear that this
car commands a premium of over
ten thousand dollars above a base GTI. Why's that?
It's what's under neath.

Changes on the Golf R are very subtle you
have new headlights you have different
bumpers front and rear.
The front bumpers have bigger air inlets to let you know you're sucking in more air
because you're going to make more power and torque.
You have different wheels the Golf R comes standard with 18-inch wheels
but this particular model we're on the upgraded 19-inch wheels.

Behind that we have the GTI Performance
Pack brakes

they're larger in diameter and behind that
this particular Golf R has adjustable
dampers that the driver can control.

They go from comfort to normal to sport
depending on what you're looking for the
card to do.

Now there's two big changes that you
should know about for the Golf R the first is
of course

engine output this car makes 292
horsepower

and 280 pound-feet of torque through a
new head, new internal components,
a new turbocharger,

it's making more power higher up in the
rev band. Now

it does weigh bit more because of
the second thing you should know and that
is the fact that this is
all-wheel-drive you have a haul deck center differential

that can selectively send torque front to
rear

depending on your traction situation up
front and it can also disengage
completely under low throttle or low speeds

for fuel economy. The car can also use
its break selectively to help limit
wheel spin or help the car turnaround,
but it also has four exhaust tips:

yeah poor exhaust tips! But the biggest
thing we're most interested in finding
out

is how it works with the stability
control completely off.

For the first time in the Golf R you
can finally defeat stability control

and we'll be real eager tofind out how
that works on the test track.

With all-wheel drive the Golf R is
much faster than the GTI

shaving nearly a second and a half off its
sixty mile an hour time

and its quarter-mile. The Golf R hit
sixty in 4.5 seconds
then passed the quarter mile in 13.1 seconds

at  104.9 miles an hour. The extra
horsepower made the Golf R slightly
faster around the figure eight
posting a best lap of 24.9 seconds.
We've had an interesting relationship with the Golf R through the ages.
We've been quite hard on it for not having
defeatable stability control and now
it finally does so let's talk about what that gives you.
When you have stability control off

it doesn't reveal any sort of magical
limits past what the Golf R can do
with the stability control on

what that stability control would do on
the track is it would intervene
so early and ruin the experience.
The stability control in this car not only is it defeatable it's
far less invasive as a whole.
So with that done with that over we can finally
enjoy the car as it was meant to be driven.

And you can imagine it was meant to
be driven very hard this is a Golf R
and R is the letter you associate with things that
are sporty or racing or fun to drive.
The word I want to associate with this car over the GTI is Premium like this is

the GTI +. The question of course for most
people is this car worth the extra ten
thousand dollars

over a GTI or a little bit over ten
thousand dollars over a base GTI?

And I think for most people the answer
is No

because you're probably not going to
appreciate the differences I think
this car's only really gonna satisfy

the Volkswagen diehards who really
appreciate the stuff you're getting in this
machine.
We are of course using the DSG a manual is

an option but it won't be available
until next year.

This is what we have available to us now
and that's okay
because the DSG is a good transmission.

I'm actually most impressed with the
overall balance of the car.

And I'm pretty impressed with the
balance in the GTI too
this is a very confidence inspiring, stable
well-balanced machine it's able to dig out of corners
pretty quickly without much fuss and it delivers some pretty strong speed quickly
without much fuss.
It feels really controled and just nicely balanced again with
not a lot
of either over or understeer it sort of digs out of corners and drives very
controllable balance way,

Which is ultimately I think what you
want from a hot hatch.

Gotta admire Volkswagen for their
tenacity at building this car they
obviously really want to make
the Golf R to be a high power, all wheel drive, stable, nice GT almost
machine

and it seems that they've done that here
this is it.
Probably the best Golf R yet.
I mean it doesn't have the wonderful sounds of that VR6 R32

but in terms of balance and body control
and again that premium sensation
this is tough to beat.

So the question is whether the Golf R is
worth the money?

If you're looking at it from the
perspective of a GTI

I suspect the answer for many is a
likely No but from the vantage of an Audi
S3 or BMW M 235 I

the Golf R gained some serious appeal
sharing the combination of performance
and refinement you'd expect of those cars at a lesser price.

The Golf R has a nice balance then it's
able to satisfy a similar driving itch as
the WRX STI

and also offers a comfort and 
functionality
to make it an extremely competent commuter car.
I mean this basically is an S3.

I'd think it's the same engine I'm not
sure if the the platforms are identical
but

like it's close enough and this is just
cheaper I think that's the

that's the thing. Because this does
just
it's essentially what it is just a well sorted Audi. It's not, it's a
nice like I'd be like uh I like my
328 D and this would be like a nice analog to the 328 D.
Like this is just a solid fun little..

title: 2015 Volkswagen Golf R: The Hot (and Refined) Hatchback - Ignition Ep. 127

comments.author: bench175

comments.text:
+Adam S Motor Trend did a comparison on their website of the new Golf R and 
the STI. Both cars were loaded, and the Limited STI with keyless and Nav 
was over $800 more expensive than the Golf R. The Golf R was slightly 
quicker, and over a second faster around Laguna Seca. A base Golf R is a 
bit more expensive than the STI, but it included a dual clutch, keyless 
entry, 12 way driver seat, leather, ect. So featured for feature they are 
priced very close. If you want a more raw experience the STI is your 
ticket, if you want a much more refined experience the Golf R is the 
choice.
comments.author: Michael Cheshareck

comments.text:
+bench175 Well for one the STi comes in at $5k cheaper.
As far as track times I haven't seen any times laid down in the Golf R to 
compare to.  Last year the WRX STi did a 3:10 at VIR for Lightning Lap, 
where the old Golf R did 3:14, so its certainly possible  the new Golf R is 
faster, but not guaranteed.
The STi basically meets your requirements, minus a small amount of interior 
quality, and possibly a bit of performance.
comments.author: Adam S (Dolby109)

comments.text:
+Adam S The STI is deficient in a few qualities. The STI is not a 
hatchback, gets 2mpg worse combined, and doesn't offer dual-clutch. The STI 
is slightly slower to 60 and slower around a track, although this is not 
that important (MT did a comparison test). The STI just isn't as nice. "In 
light of the Golf's comparatively compliant setup, the STI is busy and 
bouncy, transmitting much more of the road surface into the cabin. Throw in 
a touchier throttle, lighter steering, and noticeable turbo lag, and the 
Subaru was deemed the more frenetic of the pair" (MT).  And the STI's 
interior and exterior design is definitely more immature.  In all, it's not 
a very good alternative.
comments.author: bench175

comments.text: Uhhhhhh...a WRX STi?  And also very likely the Focus RS.

comments.author: Dinteloord

comments.text:
I feel compelled to add in here, for all the naysayers.  I love golfs, and 
I love VW's.  I've been driving them for 35 years.  Do the suggested 
maintenance, no major issues, still own a Passat GLX with 185,000 on it. 
 Love R32's have 2 of them, the one I drive has 85,000 on it, hit a deer, a 
turkey, another already dead deer and got pummeled with hail, no 
maintenance issues, love to drive it.  Why?  Put Blizzaks on it in the 
winter, its a beast on ice and most any snow and road conditions mother 
nature will dish out except more than 6 inches of fresh wet snow.  Why do 
critics always forget about fun in the snow and ice??  In the summer its 
still a beast, regularly embarrass muscle cars at the light.  It is well 
worth a $10k premium to drive safely and quickly in all 4 seasons, and for 
$10k less than a similar audi!  Also a multitude of more service centers 
for long range driving needs!  The new one sounds like a significant step 
ahead in most every sense except exhaust note.  I will miss that, but not 
when I have retained most of the power driving at altitude and with better 
mileage.  Thanks VW - again.  I will place my order soon.  ﻿

comments.author: James Gittins

comments.text: Not worth the premium price to me, would rather get the GTI myself.﻿
comments.author: Dan S

comments.text:
+Dejan Janceski What you are missing here is that this specific video that 
we are commenting on, done by Motor Trend (just like the comparison test I 
linked) is the only performance test of the new generation, 2015 Golf R. 
Edmunds hasn't tested it, Car and Driver hasn't tested it. You are probably 
looking at a 2-3 year old test from Motor Trend if you are saying the 
numbers I quoted are wrong. What Car and Driver and Edmunds have tested is 
the last generation Golf R, which had much less power, weighed more, 
handled worse, and was just plain much slower than the new 2015 Golf R. You 
tell me that I am quoting unrealistic times, but the very video that you 
are commenting on here (done by Motor Trend) as well as the link to the 
Motor Trend comparison test article, are actual numbers from actual tests 
on the 2015 Golf R. They are real world numbers, not a pie in the sky 
guess, they are actual performance numbers achieved by testing the car. I 
will hit the drag strip in the next couple months, and I should be very 
close to what Motor Trend achieved in this video, which is a very low 13 
second quarter mile. That is what people who have actually drag raced the 
cars have actually achieved. With launch control and the DSG transmission 
anyone can get these times accelerating from a new Golf R because it's as 
easy as setting launch control, flooring the gas and letting off the brake. 

Sorry for the name calling, but seriously if you are going to comment on a 
video, at least watch the video and listen to what it says before spouting 
off inaccurate information. This is on the Motor Trend channel, it is their 
official test of the 2015 Golf R, and they went 0-60 in 4.5 seconds and 
13.1@104.8mph in the quarter mile. Please look at the link in my last post 
and actually read it. That is where Motor Trend compared it to the Subaru 
STI and it gives the full performance break down on what the 2015 Golf R 
can do. Eventually Edmunds and Car and Driver will test the 2015 Golf R and 
there will be more performance data on the 2015 Golf R, but for now Motor 
Trend is all we have to go on for actual performance data. It has been 
frustrating to me that you have been unable to process the information in 
this video and Motor Trend's article, with you quoting performance times 
based on a Golf R that stopped production 2 years ago that had vastly worse 
performance than the new one. If you can't at least watch the video I guess 
I'll just refrain from responding to you because you would have to be a 
troll to comment on this video saying that the testing that Motor Trend did 
in the video is invalid because you think your 200S should perform closer 
to the new Golf R. Have a good day, sorry for the name calling, please 
actually watch and process the information in this video and the article 
that I linked.
comments.author: Michael Cheshareck

comments.text:
Wow...I see I struck a nerve.  Hey, as I said, my points I got directly 
from the MotorTrend as well as Car & Driver (and even from Edmunds).  So, 
if you have issues, take it up with them.  Your numbers that you quote 
aren't realistic real world ones.  Simple as that.  And anyone can mod a 
car to do 0-60 in sub 4 sec, and a 1/4 mile in under 12 sec.  Not 
impressive...when you have to mod the car to do that.  

BTW, you lose ALL credibility when you resort to name calling.  Stupid? 
Really?  Aren't you a bit too old to call people names anymore?
comments.author: Dejan Jancevski

comments.text:
+Dejan Jancevski are you retarded? This video is Motor Trend's test of the 
2015 Golf R, check out this link to see where it beat the STI around Laguna 
Seca and its full performance stats. 
http://www.motortrend.com/roadtests/sedans/1503_2015_subaru_wrx_sti_vs_2015_volkswagen_golf_r/ 
So far Motor Trend is the only magazine to do a full test of the US Golf R, 
so they are the only ones with valid numbers so far of the US Golf R. Car 
and Driver hasn't tested it yet, so when you say Car and Driver's stats 
don't back up what I said, they have no numbers on the car yet. So you are 
just an idiot if you think they have numbers on the 2015 Golf R 0-60 in 5.9 
seconds. Their most recent Evo that Motor Trend tested ran slower in a 
straight line, but handles better than the Golf R. The EVO needs to be 
modded to get anywhere close to 3.8 0-60 mph. The Evo is an awesome track 
car, but the Golf R is a MUCH better daily driver. You are fucking retarded 
if you think your 200C shitbox can do anything dynamically better than a 
2015 Golf R. It is universally panned for bad grip, bad handling, and a bad 
transmission. It has a lot of gadgets and fits a good amount of people, but 
an accord V6 will smoke it pretty bad. Have fun in your fantasy world of 
your 200C being a great performance car.
comments.author: Michael Cheshareck

comments.text:
+Michael Cheshareck​ your stats don't hold up to what Car & Driver or even 
what Motortend says...

But, if I was in the market for a sickly fast 4-door 4 banger....I would 
get a Mitsu Evo. No contest and only $41,575. 0-60 in 3.8 sec
comments.author: Dejan Jancevski

comments.text:
Fully loaded the Golf R is $39910 (I pain invoice, which is a bit over 
$38K), about $4000 more than a loaded GTI. For the vast increase in 
performance when equally equipped, the Golf R is worth it. Not to mention 
the Golf R holds its value much better. Now, a base GTI with Performance 
Pack and Lighting package in the $28K range is a great value for 
performance, and if I was to get a GTI that would be the spec I would get.
comments.author: Michael Cheshareck

comments.text:
+Dejan Jancevski, did you even watch the video? 0-60 in 4.5 seconds, 1/4 
mile in 13.1@104.8 mph in the 2015 Golf R, almost 2 seconds faster than you 
precious 200S. It IS blowing the doors off of a 200S by a HUGE margin. The 
2013 Golf R wasn't nearly as fast as the new one, maybe you were thinking 
about them when you made this comment? next time get a clue what the hell 
you are talking about when you comment. Watch the video and get your facts 
straight before spewing bullshit like this.
comments.author: Michael Cheshareck

comments.text:
+Michael Cheshareck​ slow??? You do realize that the 200S does 0-60 in 6.3 
sec...as does the VW Golf GTI...and that's according to Car & Driver....as 
well as Edmund's. ﻿Oh, and your precious Golf R gets there in 5.9 sec. A 
0.4 sec diff is NOT blowing the doors off of anything when you are only 
doing 60mph.
comments.author: Dejan Jancevski

comments.text:
If you want to drive a slow ass, shitty handling (by comparison) sedan by 
all means get a 200S. I'll keep enjoying my Golf R and enjoy myself as I 
blow your doors off. Just because a 200S is bigger doesn't make it a better 
car, not by a long shot. They are totally different cars with different 
audiences.
comments.author: Michael Cheshareck

comments.text:
Considering the price of either...I'd rather go with a 2015 Chrysler 200S. 
 More car for the same price.  A totally outfitted Golf GTI would come in 
around $35,950 while a comparable Chrysler 200S AWD would tip the scales 
at $36,585.  So...for merely $635 more, you get the following:

All Wheel Drive
9 speed automatic with paddle shifting (on steering wheel)
More luggage space
More interior room (about an extra 2.9 cubic feet)
Nearly identical gas mileage (despite having a V-6) PLUS the Chrysler can 
run on E85!

Sorry...just another slap happy Chrysler fan. :)

BTW, I do think that the VW Golf is a great car...but I think there are 
better cars for the money. :)
comments.author: Dejan Jancevski

comments.text:
Like someone else said after 250 hp in a front driver you need 4WD & for 
that reason alone I think it's worth the price. More then likely I would 
but something else for the price & I LOVE VW's but it Is a lot of money. 
But like all VW's they put so much into their cars that for the price you 
would spend a lot more to get that kind of quality in another car, I know 
what I said above about not buying one of these but at the same time if I 
drove it I'm sure that I could come away very impressed by the car. I would 
have to drive the Focus ST after I drove this. Even though this car is 
faster in a straight line the Ford would win the fun factor... I think.﻿

comments.text: Why I would buy that car? I'll just get a Camaro SS.﻿
comments.author: Koji Takata

comments.text: Song @ 0:25 (the intro)??﻿
comments.author: Alonso Ma

comments.text:
Some people are complaining the price vs hp and doesn't have a stick... You 
double the price you get a Z06 Z07 package (that name is hilarious tho) or 
Hellcat, with double the hp 650 and 707 hp. Sounds fair to me.

Also, dual clutch is worth much more than stick. Even something hardcore 
like Z06 doesn't have dual clutch because it'll bump up the base price by a 
couple thousand. You wanna wave some sticks during your driving, feel free 
to go with something less refined, like a Mustang.  

There is, however, one thing that is pretty bad in my opinion... The look. 
VW could put this great package inside a hull of a Jetta, or CC with better 
aerodynamics, and much cooler look.﻿
comments.author: Ray Lee

comments.text:
DSG great gear boxes until you hit peak hour traffic or the warranty ends. 
Dual clutch autos are shit from all brands and best avoided but its getter 
harder to find a traditional auto trans now.﻿
comments.author: Mark B

comments.text:
Both GTi and R are great machines. I've driven it and so enjoy. But I 
wouldn't buy because of the poor reliability. Sorry! ﻿

comments.author: Zadose18

comments.text:
As a possible Golf R driver, I feel like this video raises more questions 
than it answers.. How are fit and finish compared to the GTi? What are the 
standard features compared to the GTi? I know that automotive journalism 
has taken a turn towards the dramatic and  serious, but I think the likes 
of Carlos Lago are not nearly as light hearted as it could be. Please make 
videos more in the style of a well written Fallon monologue and less of a 
Kristen Stewart love scene.. ﻿

comments.author: bud ley

comments.text:
It's AWD, I like that, but can you attach a snow plow and make some money 
with it?  The price of "R"s is going up I've noticed. With so many 
manufactures using "R" indiscriminately there's become a shortage. 
Motorcycles are the worst offenders, they use "R" like there's no end to 
the supply. R1000RRR, the more R the faster the motorcycle is. We now have 
an over abundance of SS and GT, which used to be very popular.  ﻿
good car show with its own identity. Hard to come by these days﻿
